title: ███ exposes sensitive shipment information to public web
content:
Summary:
A subdomain of the ██████████ site exposes sensitive shipment information to the public web at ███/█████downloads/xfer_fak. Although I haven't been able to find too much info about this, it seems to be fairly sensitive and updated daily, containing over 500,000 lines just for 07/30/18. Information included looks to be many/all shipments routed under ██████:
Code 586 Bytes

10█████ services as well as a real time data feed to war fighters
████████]
Information exposed includes route information, contact names / phone numbers for each shipment,
shipment cost, content information, hazmat risk, classification level (U or C or S, likely unclass / confidential / secret), and more.
Some interesting ones:
The first listed indicates████████ materials and originates from the %E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88%E2%96%88, which is used to maintain ██████....

Step-by-step Reproduction Instructions
Visit ████/████downloads/xfer_fak.
Wait for the 30 mb response to download.
Observe that this lists over 500,000 lines of a daily summary of shipments. See above for several examples.
Impact
Not sure of the full contextual impact, but it's safe to say that this info should definitely not be publicly accessible. Day-to-day logs of over 500k lines with details of every shipment.
steps: Download and analyze the 30 MB response file containing shipment information
vuln_description: A subdomain of the ██████████ site exposes sensitive shipment information to the public web, including route details, contact names/phone numbers, shipment costs, content information, hazmat risk, and classification levels (U/C/S). The data is updated daily and contains over 500,000 lines of shipment records.
reason: The vulnerability was discovered through direct access to a publicly exposed endpoint without any authentication or complex manipulation required. The only complexity involved was identifying the sensitive nature of the data once accessed.
